C:\>eclipse.exe -vm c:\wsdk\sdk\bin\javaw.exe

What build were you trying to install?

That resource bundle should be found in
eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime_2.0.1/runtime.jar

Can you check if the file messages.properties is in that file?

From the originator:

> What build were you trying to install?

I hunted around for anything to mention it.  Not to be found.
Maybe you know were this info is keeped.  I will definitely assist in any
way I can.

>That resource bundle should be found in
>eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime_2.0.1/runtime.jar
>Can you check if the file messages.properties is in that file?

Not there.
Note: please follow-up in bugzilla instead of email.

The build number is usually accessed via Help->About.  Since you can't start,
you'll have to look at the following file:

eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.sdk.win32_<some_number>/about.mappings

There will be a line like this: "0=200206271827".  The right hand side of this
equation is the build number.
The build number found in about.mappings is 200208291828.

The message file should be in the runtime.jar under the path:
/org/eclipse/core/internal/runtime/messages.properties.

Try re-downloading the 2.0.1 build and installing that....it seems very 
strange that one particular file is missing from the jar but the rest are 
there.

Please re-open if the file is still missing from your new download.

Changed the pathname to eclipse install and now it installs without the 
following error:
java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError: java.util.MissingResourceException: 
Can't find bundle for base name org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.messages, 
locale en_US

One of the directory names in the pathname was !Share (force top of list).  
Once I replaced the (!) with (~), the resource was found and installation 
successfully completed.

This has recently shown up with another Java product.  Perhaps the (!) 
sensitive is in the java.util library.
